title: Event Segmentation Applications in Large Language Model Enabled Automated Recall Assessments
author: Ryan A. Panela (Rotman Research Institute, Baycrest Academy for Research and Education), Alexander J. Barnett (Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery, McGill University), Morgan D. Barense (Rotman Research Institute, Baycrest Academy for Research and Education), Björn Herrmann (Rotman Research Institute, Baycrest Academy for Research and Education), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate event segmentation and recall assessments, which could streamline processes in audio-language modeling and audio captioning tasks relevant to Haohe Liu's research.
background: Automating the segmentation of narratives into meaningful events and assessing memory recall using advanced LLM techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework for using Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate the processes of event segmentation and recall assessments, achieving alignment in segmentation patterns closely resembling human cognition.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for event segmentation and recall assessments have relied on subjective human judgments or more complex algorithmic approaches.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon earlier methods by leveraging LLMs, specifically demonstrating that they can replicate human event segmentation with greater consistency and less subjectivity.

key_innovation: Utilizes advanced LLMs to automate and validate segmentation of narratives, significantly enhancing scalability and efficiency in memory research.
real_world_impact: This research has the potential to revolutionize memory assessment methodologies, making them more efficient, scalable, and accessible, thereby benefiting applications in psychology and cognitive science.
limitations: The authors do not explicitly mention limitations; however, there may be concerns regarding the applicability of LLMs to all narrative types and contexts.

new_terms.event segmentation: **Event segmentation** refers to the cognitive process where individuals identify and delineate discrete events within continuous experiences.
new_terms.Large Language Models (LLMs): **Large Language Models** are advanced AI systems trained on vast text datasets, enabling them to understand and generate human-like text.
